articles.headline: Writers Go on Strike and Late Shows Go Dark
articles.snippet: How long they stay off the air is an open question. During the last strike, they gradually returned after a couple of months.
articles.abstract: How long they stay off the air is an open question. During the last strike, they gradually returned after a couple of months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just hours after the union representing thousands of television and movie writers announced that they were going on strike, hundreds of their members occupied an entire city block in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday.

articles.headline: After Pandemic Rebound, U.S. Manufacturing Droops
articles.snippet: Factories that roared out of the recession have stalled, hampering the economy, even as a new wave of production looms.
articles.abstract: Factories that roared out of the recession have stalled, hampering the economy, even as a new wave of production looms.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pandemic had a bright silver lining for Elkhart, Ind.

articles.headline: Carlson’s Text That Alarmed Fox Leaders: ‘It’s Not How White Men Fight’
articles.snippet: The discovery of the text message contributed to a chain of events that ultimately led to Tucker Carlson’s firing.
articles.abstract: The discovery of the text message contributed to a chain of events that ultimately led to Tucker Carlson’s firing.
articles.lead_paragraph: A text message sent by Tucker Carlson that set off a panic at the highest levels of Fox on the eve of its billion-dollar defamation trial showed its most popular host sharing his private, inflammatory views about violence and race.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Michael S. Schmidt and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: The ‘Peace Dividend’ Is Over in Europe. Now Come the Hard Tradeoffs.
articles.snippet: Defending against an unpredictable Russia in years to come will mean bumping up against a strained social safety net and ambitious climate transition plans.
articles.abstract: Defending against an unpredictable Russia in years to come will mean bumping up against a strained social safety net and ambitious climate transition plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 30 years since the Iron Curtain came crashing down, trillions of dollars that had been dedicated to Cold War armies and weapons systems were gradually diverted to health care, housing and schools.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: My Weekend With an Emotional Support A.I. Companion
articles.snippet: Pi, an A.I. tool that debuted this week, is a twist on the new wave of chatbots: It assists people with their wellness and emotions.
articles.abstract: Pi, an A.I. tool that debuted this week, is a twist on the new wave of chatbots: It assists people with their wellness and emotions.
articles.lead_paragraph: For several hours on Friday evening, I ignored my husband and dog and allowed a chatbot named Pi to validate the heck out of me.

articles.headline: Danish Wind Pioneer Keeps Battling Climate Change
articles.snippet: Henrik Stiesdal helped design the first modern wind turbines. A thousand patents later, he’s a green tech entrepreneur rolling out new innovations.
articles.abstract: Henrik Stiesdal helped design the first modern wind turbines. A thousand patents later, he’s a green tech entrepreneur rolling out new innovations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The contemporary wind power industry, which has spawned hundreds of thousands of spinning rotors generating electricity without putting greenhouse gases into the air, was to a great extent born in a notoriously windy region of Denmark called Jutland.

articles.headline: Companies Flock to Biden’s Climate Tax Breaks, Driving Up Cost
articles.snippet: A law to boost clean energy appears to be more potent than predicted, with big implications for both budget talks and efforts to fight climate change.
articles.abstract: A law to boost clean energy appears to be more potent than predicted, with big implications for both budget talks and efforts to fight climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden’s signature climate law appears to be encouraging more investment in American manufacturing than initially expected, powering what’s expected to be a surge in new factory jobs and domestic clean energy technologies, according to independent forecasters.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Brad Plumer

articles.headline: Fed Makes 10th Rate Increase and Opens Door to Pause
articles.snippet: The Fed raised rates by a quarter point, bringing them above 5 percent for the first time in more than 15 years.
articles.abstract: The Fed raised rates by a quarter point, bringing them above 5 percent for the first time in more than 15 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates by a quarter-point on Wednesday, the 10th straight increase in an aggressive campaign to tame rapid inflation. But they also opened the door to pausing rate increases as their policies combine with bank turmoil to weigh down the economy.

articles.headline: How U.S. Efforts to Guide Sudan to Democracy Ended in War
articles.snippet: Critics say the Biden administration and its partners were naïve about the intentions of two rival generals and failed to empower civilian leaders.
articles.abstract: Critics say the Biden administration and its partners were naïve about the intentions of two rival generals and failed to empower civilian leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just weeks ago, American diplomats thought Sudan was on the verge of a breakthrough agreement that would advance its transition from military dictatorship to full-fledged democracy, delivering on the soaring promise of the country’s revolution in 2019.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Jack Dorsey Has a Lot to Say, Including About Elon Musk and Twitter
articles.snippet: The Twitter co-founder has posted prolifically on two new social networks, Nostr and Bluesky, which he also backed financially.
articles.abstract: The Twitter co-founder has posted prolifically on two new social networks, Nostr and Bluesky, which he also backed financially.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Dorsey has barely posted on Twitter, the social media platform he helped create, since January. In two of his last tweets, the billionaire entrepreneur promoted an app for Nostr, a new social network.
